country_overview.content: France, renowned for its rich history, art, fashion, and cuisine, is one of the most visited countries in the world. From the iconic Eiffel Tower in Paris to the beautiful beaches of the French Riviera and the historic castles of the Loire Valley, France offers a diverse array of attractions. The country's visa policy is aligned with the Schengen Agreement, making it accessible for tourists from around the world who meet the requirements.

tourist_visa.title: Tourist Visa
tourist_visa.description: The Schengen Tourist Visa allows visitors to stay in France and other Schengen Area countries for up to 90 days within a 180-day period. This visa is ideal for travelers visiting France for leisure, sightseeing, or to visit friends and family.

business_visa.title: Business Visa
business_visa.description: The Schengen Business Visa is intended for individuals who need to visit France for business purposes, such as attending meetings, conferences, or signing contracts. This visa also permits stays of up to 90 days within a 180-day period.

student_visa.title: Student Visa
student_visa.description: The Student Visa is for foreign nationals who wish to study at a French educational institution. This visa is typically valid for the duration of the course, with options for renewal. Students may also work part-time during their studies.

work_visa.title: Work Visa
work_visa.description: The Work Visa is required for individuals who have secured employment in France. It allows for long-term residency and is typically linked to the duration of the employment contract. Employers must sponsor this visa.

long_stay_visa.title: Long-Stay Visa
long_stay_visa.description: The Long-Stay Visa, or 'Visa de Long Séjour,' is for those who intend to stay in France for more than 90 days. This visa can be issued for various purposes, including study, work, or family reunification.

tourist_visa.eligibility_criteria: Applicants must have a valid passport, proof of accommodation, sufficient financial means, and a clear purpose for visiting France. The intention to leave France before the visa expires must also be demonstrated.
mandatory_documents: Valid passport with at least six months of validity
Proof of accommodation (hotel bookings, invitation letter, etc.)
additional_documents: Proof of employment or studies in the home country

business_visa.eligibility_criteria: Applicants must be invited by a French company or organization for business purposes. Proof of business activities and the intention to return to the home country after the visit are required.
mandatory_documents: Valid passport with at least six months of validity
Invitation letter from the French company
Proof of business activities (e.g., contracts, correspondence)
additional_documents: Previous business correspondence with the inviting company

student_visa.eligibility_criteria: Applicants must have been accepted into a recognized educational institution in France and must be able to demonstrate financial ability to support their studies and stay in the country.
mandatory_documents: Valid passport with at least six months of validity
Acceptance letter from the educational institution
Proof of financial support (e.g., bank statements)

step_1.title: Determine Visa Type
step_1.description: Identify the appropriate visa type based on your purpose of travel to France. Ensure that you meet the eligibility criteria for the chosen visa category.

step_2.title: Check Eligibility
step_2.description: Review the specific eligibility requirements for the visa type you are applying for. This may include health checks, financial requirements, and documentation needs.

step_3.title: Gather Required Documents
step_3.description: Collect all necessary documents, including the visa application form, passport, photographs, and supporting documents relevant to your visa type.

step_4.title: Fill Out the Application Form
step_4.description: Complete the visa application form accurately. You can usually find the form on the official website of the French embassy or consulate in your country.

step_5.title: Submit the Application
step_5.description: Submit your completed application form along with the required documents at the nearest French embassy or consulate. In some cases, online submission may be available.

step_6.title: Wait for Processing
step_6.description: The processing time varies depending on the visa type and your country of residence. Ensure that you provide any additional information if requested by the visa authorities.

step_7.title: Receive the Visa
step_7.description: Once your visa is approved, you will be notified to collect it. Ensure that all the details on the visa are correct before your travel.

visa_fees.content: Visa fees vary depending on the type of visa, the number of entries, and the nationality of the applicant. The fees are non-refundable and must be paid at the time of application. Fees can be paid online or through the embassy/consulate.

processing_time.content: Processing times for French visas generally range from 10 to 20 business days, depending on the type of visa and your country of residence. It is advisable to apply well in advance of your planned travel date.

visa_validity.content: The validity of a French visa depends on the type and number of entries allowed. For example, Schengen visas can be valid for 90 days within a 180-day period, while long-stay visas may be valid for several months or years, depending on the purpose.

entry_requirements.content: Upon arrival in France, travelers must present their valid visa, passport, and sometimes proof of accommodation and sufficient funds. It's essential to adhere to the entry requirements to avoid complications at the border.

faq_1.question: Can I extend my visa while in France?
faq_1.answer: Yes, certain visas can be extended while you are in France. You need to apply for an extension at the local Prefecture before your current visa expires.

faq_2.question: Is visa-free entry available for France?
faq_2.answer: France offers visa-free entry for citizens of certain countries, particularly within the EU/EEA and select other countries. However, most nationalities are required to obtain a visa prior to arrival.

faq_3.question: Can I work in France on a tourist visa?
faq_3.answer: No, working on a tourist visa is strictly prohibited. You must apply for a work visa if you intend to work in France legally.
